title: Can a six string bass guitar be strung with normal strings to accommodate larger hands? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m assuming, after reading some answers here that by “normal” strings you mean regular guitar strings strung on a six string bass because you want to play a regular guitar but feel like your hands are too big. The idea would be to have an instrument with a longer scale and wider string spacing to accommodate your particular hands. After 20+ years of teaching guitar and seeing many hands and fingers up close, I would say that there is a certain small percentage of people who have hands entirely unsuitable for standard guitars. I would also suggest that if you’re seeing a violinist or some other instrumentalist playing successfully, you’re seeing a person whose hands are suitable (at least close enough) for their instrument and they’re not playing pieces their hands can’t perform. You’re not seeing the number of people who didn’t make it, gave up or switched to another instrument because of hand issues. So, the people I have seen with hands unsuitable for regular guitars include: hands that are massive- it’s not so much the hand size that’s a problem but fingertip thickness and string spacing. The fingers are too thick to be positioned so that adjacent strings can ring clearly. My dad is one of these people- he can play limited things on a classical guitar but his hands are actually ideal for bass guitar. My mother has slender fingers so I got a combination of big hands with slender fingers. I also got a “short” pinky which causes me some problems. It’s not really short but rather set lower on my hand.Fingernails that can’t be cut short enough. Some people have nails that when cut as short as possible they still stick out past the fingertip. This creates enormous difficulty for the left hand (fretting hand). A scalloped fretboard might be a solution as well as bass guitar if the hands are big enough. Bass strings are thick enough that some extra nail length won’t interfere so much with the left hand.Also, I took lessons with Peppino D’Agostino years ago and he was touring with Seagull steel string guitars. I asked why he used that instrument and he told me it was because they made the string spacing wider than normal and that was the only guitar he could play with his “fat fingers”. The thing about guitars is that buying guitars is kind of like buying clothes- manufacturers make instruments that are sized to be close for fitting a majority of the population. People on the extremes of that range have difficulty. Ideally, instruments would be custom made to fit a person’s particular hands. I’ve done this myself- my pinky finger is set a little low on my hand and my middle and ring fingers are long, making it difficult to do some things in the higher register on my classical guitar. I had a guitar hand built by Thomas Humphrey because his standard design for classical guitar has the neck raised above the fingerboard, making it easier to reach the higher registers. His guitar is a much better fit for my particular hands. There’s things I play on that guitar that are much easier than on a standard concert guitar and there are things I can play on a cutaway guitar that are easier than those. While I like your creative idea, stringing a six string bass with regular guitar strings will be problematic. The scale length is much longer on a bass, it may need a new nut to fit the smaller sized strings and it won’t really play like a guitar. It may be worth trying though you’d have to figure out what tuning the strings will allow. If I were you, I’d do a few things. Check with a guitar teacher to make sure your hands really are too big and that you’re not making some other error making the problem worse (posture, hand position, how you hold the guitar etc). Have he teacher also check the guitar’s setup as the setup has a big influence on how guitars play. Try some existing options for guitars as guitars do come in various scale lengths etc. Baritone guitars are bigger but still feel more like a guitar than a bass. They are tuned lower, which means you’ll have to take that into account depending on the music you’re playing. If none of that works, I’d look into getting a custom instrument. It’s possible that a slightly longer scale length with wider string spacing may work for you. The problem with this is a custom instrument will cost more and you won’t be able to try it before hand. There may be a luthier who has experience with this and can measure your hands and maybe give you some specific advice based on those measurements. The other option is to just switch to bass- you may find that you like bass a lot. You could get a bass like a six string or seven string which would give you more strings for soloing in a higher register. Consider that good bass players are always in demand on the music scene. Good luck!

I disagree with several answers below, but agree that overall the bass restring is not a good idea. In addition to tuners and the like, one would have to replace the nut and bridge to accommodate skinnier strings and variation in scale length that compensates for different tensions. Also, the pick-ups are designed for a different frequency range. Using a bass with different strings does not mess up the pitch intervals. On a standard guitar, each fret going up is in the same ratio to the remaining length of the string as the next fret. The ratios apply to all scale lengths including kiddie, regular, baritone, and bass guitars. As an example for string fatness, changing from DR Drop-Down heavy strings to Ernie Ball Super Slinkys does not change the pitch intervals. Some guitarists do have very big hands. Terry Kath from Chicago (RIP) had large hands, but sure could roll through those jazzy arpeggios. Just listen to the intro to “Questions 67 and 68”. While you’re at it take note of the rich full bass tone that Peter Cetera produced. I’m told that Andy Summers of the Police would use wide chord frettings (that few others could reach) on purpose so his stuff would be difficult to replicate. Form the chords that Summers picks in “I’ll Be Watching You” (at least I had trouble with it). Just work with that guitar you have. It will pay you back. A baritone, as suggested, might be an idea.

First, even large hands would find a bass guitar scale length too large for guitar playing. The frets are too wide to make barre chords and certain shapes too difficult than they should be. What I’m saying is that one should instead practice on the instrument regardless of the hand size relative to the fretboard. Ukulele and violin players don’t have issues with it, and others shouldn’t as well. Theoretically though, no. Guitar strings are typically too short to actually reach the pegs. If they do, there’s not enough string to wind them. Add to that the problem of the actual tuners. They have different gear ratios to guitar machine heads. Unless you find a suitable replacement which will most likely involve rigging or replacing the headstock, tuning the strings would present problems instead. Add to that the increased tension on the strings. Because of the scale length, one would need to tune up a string with more tension, which can become uncomfortable. If one wants to find a longer scale length to work with, then a baritone guitar might be suitable. It is tuned lower than a guitar due to its length, but it does provide wider frets. The only catch is, if you wanted to play in the register of the guitar, you would have to access upper frets anyway, negating the advantages of wider frets.

This question lacks enough specificity to answer. Bass guitar strings have larger gauges compared to electric guitar or acoustic guitar strings. Maybe you’re asking if you can throw acoustic guitar strings on a bass guitar. In that case, you’d be a pioneer. Normal strings doesn’t confirm any kind of musical instrument string.
What do you mean by ‘normal strings’? Normal for a 6-string bass? Strings have little impact on hands - it’s the scale of the instrument that makes all the difference.
